8f88da38-ac40-4c93-b7b0-696ec02cea7a.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload
8f88da38-ac40-4c93-b7b0-696ec02cea7a.description:
This threat vector represents a sophisticated multi-stage infection chain employed by Pakistan-aligned 
APT groups to compromise Indian defense and government entities. The attack begins with a spearphishing 
email containing a malicious LNK file disguised as a legitimate document. When executed by the victim, 
the LNK file leverages mshta.exe to retrieve and execute an HTA file from attacker-controlled infrastructure.

The HTA file contains JavaScript code that decrypts and loads an embedded DLL payload, which subsequently 
writes a decoy PDF to disk, establishes C2 communication, and displays the decoy to the user. Before 
deploying the final payload (Geta RAT), the malware performs security software discovery to adapt its 
persistence mechanism, demonstrating defense-aware behaviour.

The technique's effectiveness stems from combining social engineering, abuse of trusted system binaries 
(Living Off The Land), multi-stage execution, and dynamic evasion techniques. The use of compromised 
legitimate domains for payload hosting further reduces detection probability and increases victim trust.

cb0a2cd0-510b-412b-9d79-2fe5394b15b3.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS
cb0a2cd0-510b-412b-9d79-2fe5394b15b3.description:
CVE-2026-2441 represents a critical use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome's CSS rendering engine that 
was actively exploited as a zero-day before patch availability. The vulnerability enables remote code 
execution within the browser sandbox through crafted HTML pages, requiring only user navigation to a 
malicious URL with no additional user interaction needed.

Google acknowledged active exploitation but witeld details on threat actors and targets, suggesting 
sophisticated threat activity potentially targeting high-value individuals or organisations. The rapid 
two-day window between discovery and patch release indicates the severity and active exploitation status.

This threat vector exemplifies modern browser exploitation techniques where initial access is achieved 
through memory corruption vulnerabilities, providing a foothold for further exploitation including 
sandbox escape, credential harvesting, and persistent implant deployment.

323d773d-d1ba-4fb8-b43a-0dfe70d492d7.name: Commercial Mobile Spyware Enabling Real-Time Surveillance and Financial Theft via Fake App Distribution
323d773d-d1ba-4fb8-b43a-0dfe70d492d7.description:
ZeroDayRAT is a commercial cross-platform mobile spyware platform advertised on Telegram that enables 
comprehensive device surveillance and financial theft on Android and iOS devices. The platform provides 
buyers with a malware builder and self-hosted management panel, offering capabilities including real-time 
GPS tracking, keystroke logging, SMS interception (including OTPs), account enumeration, live camera and 
microphone streaming, cryptocurrency wallet manipulation, and banking credential theft. Distributed via 
social engineering and fake app marketplaces, the spyware exemplifies the commoditisation of sophisticated 
mobile surveillance capabilities previously limited to nation-state actors, making comprehensive mobile 
compromise accessible to a broader range of threat actors through a commercial offering.

bff2f55e-8100-4d10-9172-9a3b1171268f.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload
bff2f55e-8100-4d10-9172-9a3b1171268f.description:
This detection objective aims to identify and alert on multi-stage infection chains that leverage 
malicious LNK files to execute mshta.exe for deploying HTA-embedded payloads. This attack pattern 
is commonly employed by APT36 (Transparent Tribe) and SideCopy groups targeting Indian defense 
and government entities.

The objective focuses on detecting the complete attack chain from initial phishing delivery through 
to payload execution and persistence establishment, with particular emphasis on Living Off The Land 
Binary (LOLBin) abuse and defense-aware behaviour patterns.

da5a73a9-0d72-4c0b-b003-bce1e8c69be4.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload::LNK File Execution Invoking MSHTA
da5a73a9-0d72-4c0b-b003-bce1e8c69be4.description:
Detects execution of mshta.exe spawned by Windows Explorer or other shell processes where the 
parent process chain indicates LNK file interaction. This signal identifies the initial execution 
vector where malicious shortcut files invoke mshta.exe to retrieve and execute remote HTA payloads.

Key indicators include mshta.exe with command-line arguments pointing to remote URLs (http/https), 
particularly when the parent process is explorer.exe or when process creation events coincide with 
LNK file access events.

b16fe51a-7e03-4cbe-9be3-05e32f94a651.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload::MSHTA Retrieving Remote HTA from Compromised Legitimate Domain
b16fe51a-7e03-4cbe-9be3-05e32f94a651.description:
Identifies mshta.exe establishing network connections to retrieve HTA files from external sources, 
with particular focus on compromised legitimate domains. This signal detects the payload retrieval 
stage where the malicious HTA file is downloaded from attacker-controlled infrastructure.

The detection should correlate network connection events with mshta.exe process execution and 
analyse destination reputation, categorisation, and historical access patterns to identify 
anomalous or suspicious connections.

db380d91-f8d2-48f3-a7ba-9753061b2248.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload::HTA Execution with Embedded JavaScript Performing DLL Operations
db380d91-f8d2-48f3-a7ba-9753061b2248.description:
Detects execution of obfuscated JavaScript within HTA files that perform DLL-related operations 
such as decryption, file writing, or loading. This signal identifies the payload decryption and 
deployment stage where the HTA-embedded JavaScript decrypts and loads the malicious DLL.

Key detection points include monitoring for script execution events showing JavaScript/VBScript 
operations involving file system writes to temporary directories, cryptographic operations (base64 
decoding, XOR operations), and subsequent DLL loading events.

0bfea4b7-05c6-4597-8c62-ace5b922199d.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload::Security Software Discovery Following MSHTA Execution
0bfea4b7-05c6-4597-8c62-ace5b922199d.description:
Identifies security software enumeration activity occurring shortly after mshta.exe execution or 
DLL loading events. This signal detects defense-aware behaviour where the malware surveys the 
security landscape before establishing persistence or deploying final payloads.

Detection focuses on registry queries targeting security software installation paths, service 
enumeration for AV/EDR products, and process listing activities that correlate temporally with 
the earlier stages of the attack chain.

af7a8a0f-79b8-4b59-9915-41ef63471692.name: Phishing Delivery via LNK File Executing MSHTA to Deploy HTA-Embedded DLL Payload::Decoy PDF Display Concurrent with C2 Communication
af7a8a0f-79b8-4b59-9915-41ef63471692.description:
Detects the simultaneous occurrence of PDF file creation/display and network communication to 
suspicious external hosts. This signal identifies the social engineering component where a decoy 
document is presented to the victim whilst malicious C2 communication is established in the background.

The detection correlates file creation events for PDF files in user-accessible directories with 
outbound network connections to non-standard ports or suspicious destinations occurring within a 
short time window.

5ef0bc94-2e80-4f13-94cc-18976ddb7622.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS
5ef0bc94-2e80-4f13-94cc-18976ddb7622.description:
Detect exploitation of CVE-2026-2441, a use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome's CSS engine
that enables remote code execution via crafted HTML pages. This actively exploited zero-day
allows threat actors to achieve arbitrary code execution within the browser sandbox, potentially
leading to data theft, credential harvesting, or as a stepping stone for full system compromise.

The detection objective focuses on identifying malicious browser activity patterns, suspicious
process behaviors, and network indicators associated with exploitation attempts targeting
unpatched Chrome installations (versions prior to 145.0.7632.75).

2f83ab03-12ee-4379-a648-e6444675eb91.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS::Chrome Process Crash with Memory Corruption Indicators
2f83ab03-12ee-4379-a648-e6444675eb91.description:
Detects Chrome browser crashes potentially indicative of exploitation attempts. Use-after-free
vulnerabilities typically cause memory corruption that may result in process termination. While
crashes can be benign, patterns of crashes on specific pages or unusual crash reports may indicate
active exploitation. This signal focuses on chrome.exe crashes with error codes or crash dump
characteristics associated with memory corruption (access violations, heap corruption).

d010b507-616f-4265-8b99-597a53ddc393.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS::Chrome Spawning Unexpected Child Processes
d010b507-616f-4265-8b99-597a53ddc393.description:
Identifies chrome.exe spawning child processes that are uncommon for normal browser operation.
Successful exploitation within the sandbox may lead to attempts to execute additional code or
escape containment. Suspicious child processes include cmd.exe, powershell.exe, wscript.exe,
cscript.exe, or other scripting/execution utilities not typically spawned by Chrome during
normal web browsing. Excludes known legitimate Chrome child processes like chrome.exe itself
(multi-process architecture), crashpad_handler.exe, and software_reporter_tool.exe.

5472e9b5-1bf5-497f-9472-a2026463bb2c.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS::Network Connection to Newly Registered or Low-Reputation Domains
5472e9b5-1bf5-497f-9472-a2026463bb2c.description:
Detects Chrome browser connections to domains with low reputation scores, newly registered
domains (registered within last 30-90 days), or domains using suspicious TLDs commonly
associated with malicious infrastructure. Exploit delivery often leverages compromised
legitimate sites or newly created attacker-controlled domains. This signal correlates
Chrome network connections with threat intelligence feeds and domain reputation services
to identify potentially malicious C2 or exploit delivery infrastructure.

6ed5d84f-95cc-4228-9a6d-91452b5b8588.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS::Chrome Accessing Unusual File System Locations
6ed5d84f-95cc-4228-9a6d-91452b5b8588.description:
Identifies Chrome process accessing file system paths outside of its normal operational
directories. Typical Chrome file access is limited to user profile directories, cache,
cookies, extensions, and download folders. Access to system directories (Windows\\System32,
ProgramData), administrative shares, or attempts to write to executable directories may
indicate post-exploitation activity such as payload staging, persistence establishment,
or lateral movement preparation.

f107753a-dd10-4c26-a945-498abd3f453d.name: Browser Exploitation via Chrome CVE-2026-2441 Use-After-Free in CSS::Suspicious Browser Extension Installation or Modification
f107753a-dd10-4c26-a945-498abd3f453d.description:
Detects installation or modification of Chrome browser extensions outside of normal user-
initiated workflows. Post-exploitation persistence may involve installing malicious
extensions to maintain access, intercept credentials, or exfiltrate data. This signal
monitors for unexpected changes to Chrome's extension directories, registry keys associated
with extension policies, or API calls related to extension installation not preceded by
user interaction with Chrome Web Store.

d076a0a4-e467-4346-99a3-5dd011a2df04.name: Chrome Spawning Unexpected Child Processes
d076a0a4-e467-4346-99a3-5dd011a2df04.description:
Detects Google Chrome browser spawning suspicious child processes that are uncommon for normal
web browsing operations. This detection targets post-exploitation activity associated with
CVE-2026-2441, a use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome's CSS engine enabling sandboxed remote
code execution.

Chrome's multi-process architecture normally spawns only specific child processes (chrome.exe
instances for renderers/GPU, crashpad_handler.exe for crash reporting, software_reporter_tool.exe
for cleanup). Execution of scripting utilities (cmd.exe, powershell.exe, wscript.exe, cscript.exe)
or other system binaries indicates potential exploitation and sandbox escape attempts.

This rule filters out legitimate Chrome child processes while alerting on high-risk execution
patterns that suggest compromise.

edbc828b-6b51-4aa5-8d7f-c33c41b65282.name: LNK File Execution Invoking MSHTA
edbc828b-6b51-4aa5-8d7f-c33c41b65282.description:
Detects execution of mshta.exe spawned by Windows Explorer or other shell processes where the 
parent process chain indicates LNK file interaction. This detection identifies the initial execution 
vector where malicious shortcut files invoke mshta.exe to retrieve and execute remote HTA payloads.

The detection focuses on identifying mshta.exe process creation events with command-line arguments 
pointing to remote URLs (http/https), particularly when the parent process is explorer.exe. This 
pattern is highly indicative of malicious LNK files being used as an initial access vector.

Key indicators monitored:
- mshta.exe process creation
- Parent process is explorer.exe (shell context)
- Command line contains HTTP/HTTPS URLs
- Process spawned in user context (not system services)

This detection is part of a multi-stage detection objective covering the complete attack chain 
from phishing delivery through post-exploitation activities.
